channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Montel Williams, The Sailing of the Intrepid
channel.desc: Former talk show host Montel Williams, who served with the U.S. Navy and Marines for over 20 years, and co-author David Fisher discuss the history of the USS Intrepid, an aircraft carrier that played a key role in several campaigns during WWII.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: The Presidency
channel.desc: CNN legal analyst Jeffrey Toobin looks at the origins and politics of the president's right to pardon using Gerald Ford's 1974 pardon of his predecessor, Richard Nixon, as a case study.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: After Words
channel.desc: A guest host who shares an interest in the subject matter and a non-fiction author pair up to discuss the author's writings.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Robert Brigham, This is a True War Story
channel.desc: Vassar College professor Robert Brigham discusses his upcoming memoir about his search for his biological father, who served as a Marine in Vietnam.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Mark Daley, Safe - A Memoir of Fatherhood, Foster Care, and the Risks We Take for Family
channel.desc: Coverage of the 2024 Wisconsin Book Festival in Madison.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Edna Bonhomme, A History of the World in Six Plagues
channel.desc: Edna Bonhomme looks at how plagues, including cholera, the Spanish flu and COVID-19, have shaped society.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Mike Tidwell, The Lost Trees of Willow Avenue
channel.desc: Activist Mike Tidwell examines the impact of climate change on his neighborhood in Maryland; he is interviewed by Rep. Jamie Raskin at the Takoma Park, Md., Community Center.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Melanie Phillips, The Builder's Stone
channel.desc: British columnist Melanie Phillips talks about the contributions of Jews and Christians to the development of the west; she argues that they are the only hope for saving western civilization today.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Source Booksellers - 2025 Publishers Weekly Bookstore of the Year
channel.desc: Source Bookselllers owner Janet Webster Jones discusses the independent bookstore in Detroit's Midtown district and what she's learned over more than two decades in the bookselling business.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Rachel Frazin, Poisoning the Well - How Forever Chemicals Contaminated America
channel.desc: Rachel Frazin talks about the proliferation of PFAS chemicals and their effects on human health and the environment.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Washington Journal
channel.desc: A segment from a recent Washington Journal.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Jocelyn Benson, The Purposeful Warrior
channel.desc: Michigan Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson discusses her life and career in politics, including her experience facing armed protestors at her home after certifying Joe Biden's victory in Michigan after the 2020 presidential election.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Edward Tenner, Why the Hindenburg Had a Smoking Lounge
channel.desc: Author Edward Tenner examines the unintended effects of science and technological developments; the American Philosophical Society in Philadelphia hosts this event.

channel.title: Lectures in History
channel.desc: Boston College communications professor Michael Serazio discusses how baseball connects Americans to their past and culture.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Reel America
channel.desc: A 1951 Armed Forces Information Service film dramatizes the effects of an imagined Communist invasion on an American small town.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: The Presidency
channel.desc: Even the food at the White House is political - and imbued with cultural and diplomatic messages. This is a day-long symposium featuring a former White House chef, food historians, and White House scholars.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: The Presidency
channel.desc: Even the food at the White House is political - and imbued with cultural and diplomatic messages. This is a day-long symposium featuring a former White House chef, food historians, and White House scholars.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Reel America
channel.desc: This 1938 New York Port Authority film covers the planning, construction and operation of the Lincoln Tunnel, which connects New York to New Jersey and opens in December 1937.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: The Civil War
channel.desc: The American Civil War Museum in Richmond, Virginia, hosts authors and historians discussing Civil War topics.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Frank Garmon, a Wonderful Career in Crime
channel.desc: Author Frank Garmon discusses Charles Cowlam's career as a convict, spy, detective, congressional candidate, adventurer and con artist during the Civil War era.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: International Spy Museum Tour
channel.desc: International Spy Museum historian and curator Andrew Hammond highlights espionage tools and artifacts from the museum's collection.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Joyce Chaplin, The Franklin Stove
channel.desc: Harvard University professor Joyce Chaplin talks about Benjamin Franklin as a scientist and how the stove he invented in 1742 became a popular product in and beyond the U.S.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Bennett Parten, Somewhere Toward Freedom
channel.desc: Author Bennett Parten discusses Union General William Sherman's 1864 March to the Sea, a critical Civil War campaign that destroyed the Confederacy, from the perspective of the enslaved people who fled to the Union lines.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Reel America
channel.desc: Documenting research and development conducted by the U.S. Postal Service and its efforts to improve safety and speed of mail processing through technology.

channel.name: CSPAN 3 US
channel.title: Supreme Court Civil Rights Mystery
channel.desc: The U.S. Supreme Court chamber is the setting for a lecture about African American law student Lloyd Gaines, who challenged a law school's segregation policy - but then disappeared after the court ruled in his favor in 1938.
